displayed_text: Patient: I, yeah, I, um, for now on, I’m trying to do them here. I don’t want to --- Doctor: Are we doin’ it on the same day or are you coming in early or? Family Member: We should – they want you to come in early so they can have something – Patient: The appointment for the twenty-fifth, she wanted me to come in a few days earlier. The nurse was saying --- Family Member: A week early. Or Doctor: The same would be true for me in April, if you could do it early? Patient: Yeah, yeah. I will. Doctor: You could do it the same day, but then we don’t – Patient: No, I will. Doctor: But I just have to tell you about aliens, and I’ve got nothing else to talk to you about. Patient: Well, yeah, I know. I’ll get my daughter over here. (Laughs) Doctor: Okay.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.2 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::2 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.neutral: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::neutral

A doctor would never mislead you about a.disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.neutral: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::neutral

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.neutral: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::neutral

People of my ethnic group are treated th.neutral: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::neutral

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.Post high school training other than col: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Post high school training other than college (vocational or technical)

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.White: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::White

displayed_text: Family Member: It’s being done for die- his diabetic condition. Doctor: Right. Patient: Yeah. So how do I counter that? Doctor: That’s where you have to go to a nephrologist ‘cause they’re smarter than me. Patient: Okay. (laughs) Doctor: They gotta work with the kidney and in your case it really is the kidney. Patient: Yeah, right. Family Member: Yes, yes. Doctor: Um and it just depends on where you want to see this person. I’m – Do you see the B______ docs? Patient: Yes. Family Member: Yes. Doctor: Yep. Are a R____ or T____?

Family Member: So this other doctor is going to explain the side effects he may get from radiation? Doctor: Yeah, so when you see Dr. B____, so that’s another Dr. B, you’re going to listen about what can or can’t you do, why is it once a month, what are your obligations. What are the potential side effects and how does he want to see you and he might need blood work kind of not on day of because there’s a half-life to the medicine as in if he knows the week before your counts are good to go then he can order it and when you show up it’s here and you get it. Patient: Okay. Doctor: If he orders it and you show up and uh-oh you can’t get it, there’s, we’re in trouble. Patient: Right, Okay. Doctor: That’s fifteen thousand you might have to just flush down the toilet because you can’t save it for the next week because it starts to decay and you can’t give it to somebody else so. Patient: Okay, I’m good with that. That sounds good. Okay? Doctor: It’s okay. Patient: I happy with it. Doctor: Great. You guys had a lot of good questions today. Patient: We learned to ask. You got to speak up. That’s right. Doctor: You got to advocate for yourself. Right? That’s absolutely the one thing. So, very good. Patient: So, that’s good news that we can travel. I like being able to see the grandkids you know.

Patient: I see. Doctor: So but it can never be like you get the pill and you get the placebo Pill that can't ever happen. That's just not ethical. And the IRB and all of our regulatory people would literally have spazz attack and we would never do that. Patient: Okay. Family Member 3: Okay. Doctor: So just to put that at ease. You know, it's- there's a lot of myths going around. And some of it is founded in just the confusion, you know, like, we’ve gotten so complicated on how we do things now. And sometimes the description of that explanation isn't as maybe as thorough or you just, you know, I may say it, but you didn't really receive it. So there's a lot of that and the more complicated we get with our treatments, the worse that occurs. And to tell you the truth, part of the things that we always try to study and why you guys are graciously signed up is, you know, I may say something go, “No, no, no, I reviewed that with them.” And you guys are like, “Oh, honey, I've never heard it.” So we want to make sure whatever we're doing actually could be optimized, because it is complicated. Family Member 1: So you are going to put him on the docetaxel pill? Doctor: Right or you might get on just the regular IV. So the trial is not that you get both, but you're one or the other. Family Member 1: When will you know that? Doctor: Yeah, so this is where it gets complicated. I'm gonna have my research nurse M_____ come in, it's always the devils in the details. Family Member 1: Okay. Doctor: What's tight about this and what's goofy about it and we've already shared this with a company is that they almost want to be like, okay, we know everything about you. And then two weeks later, you have to start. So there's a time thing that's so compressed, that I even fear that you might even, you know, need another CAT scan, because they only want everything done in a two week window. So if that's the case, obviously, she'll time it out. But I defer to the research team to make sure that that's done correctly. And I've learned over the years to basically zip it because I say something they're like, “Yeah, no, you just botched up that schedule.” So I just stay out of it and let Melanie take over. Patient: Okay.

Family Member: Not for now. Okay. That’s good news. Doctor: You know, but someday maybe. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: I mean, it is an effective thing we use, but I think we have other things to try before. Family Member: Awesome. (sighs) Doctor: Okay? Patient: Okay. So, are we, or why, are we trying these other things because - and it could be both answers - because you want to know? Or because, they’re the most effective options for me? Doctor: So. (Pause) Patient: I don’t want to compromise your ethical considerations. Doctor: So, in the realm of standard treatment, the two treatments that we have that are new hormonal treatments, we call them “Second Line Treatments.” So, the, the Lupron/Eligard is the first one. We would add a second one. Both of those have been tested in big clinical trials, and both of those showed an improvement in survival for a large group of men. It wasn’t a huge improvement. Um. But it reduced your risk of dying of prostate cancer by about thirty percent. The survival improvement was on the order of months, but that is really, uh, for the whole group. It’s hard to call the individuals outta that. Um, so that’s kind of the baseline that we know. Um. And, those drugs, you know, they have side effects that we need to manage, but that’s kind of would be the next treatment that’s standard treatment. It’s approved by the FDA because of the survival improvement. The new finding about this new drug, they’re called “PARP” inhibitors. A group did a study in England where they had fifty guys who had some DNA mutation, mostly BRCA2. They treated the fifty guys; sixteen had mutations. And, they found that none of the people without the mutations responded. Fourteen of the sixteen - so, you know, ninety percent who had a mutation responded to these drugs very well. Suggesting, they’re probably going to work really well in patients like that. Um. Patient: Am I one of those people? Doctor: Yeah, you’re one of those people. Now, that drug hasn’t been through the big paces of FDA trial approval. That’s where it is right now. So, the trials we’re looking at are looking at giving that drug alone or in combination with these standard hormones. So, the trial that I would consider for you have multiple arms. We could talk about that in detail, but, it’s there’s two different trials they could either combine the drugs or give you one drug. Um. But, the, but the, where the field is moving is there’s going to be fifty trials of this to try to nail this down.

Patient: So did you like Budapest? Doctor: Yes, it was interesting. I mean I had limited time, but it was… Patient: Yeah we did too. Doctor: I don’t think I would have ever thought of Budapest to visit if it weren’t for this meeting where I to be there. Patient: Yeah yeah right. Well we had been there. Doctor: It’s an incredible city. Oh my gosh! Like I never knew about, never thought about. Patient: And we never had enough time either. Doctor: Really? Even you went on your cruise right? Family Member: We were supposed to be there two days but then we had some problems with the boat so we had – they limited it to one day. They had to cut out some things. Doctor: And you thought that wasn’t… Patient: No. Family Member: No.

Patient: My hormone shot. Doctor: I don’t know if you – if you get a hormone shot in January and it’s six months, you won’t need another one until July. So, that April version will just be a PSA check and see how we’re doing Patient: Right. Family Member: Right. Doctor: And maybe some more discussion. Family Member: Because that will be at least his third hormone shot. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: And at some point, everybody’s saying those will stop working or could stop working. Doctor: They could stop working. Um. They will stop working eventually. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: I mean, usually, it takes a year or two. But, they will stop eventually. Family Member: Okay.

Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Yes. And then, of course, you know, we do do this, and I really want you to consider, you know, donating the extra bloods as we go throughout the year because I get to follow you for this whole time anyways. Family Member: Oh, okay. Doctor: So it’s not like you have to come back, and he’s, it’s just when you come back, when we stick you, we can get up to like ten extra tubes of blood because it’s that much we have to check. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: Your immune system is really complicated. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: So we have to check everything. Family Member: Wow. Doctor: Yeah. So there’s no sticking or biopsies but it’s a blood draw. And you have lots to spare. So don’t say, “Oh, my, God”. Doctor: “She can take this ten and that’s it. I’m rolling out of here.” No. You have lots, and lots, and lots of blood to donate. Okay? Family Member: Oh, okay.

Patient: Oh, my God! Wow Doctor: But I didn’t know it was my patient because rightly so they didn’t allow him to call from his cellphone. Patient: That makes sense. Doctor: So they had to call from the border. Oh, man! So then I was like oh, my gosh, then I was like well, how do I know you are who you say you are so I gave it right back to him and I go so, you know, what’s your phone number so just to be safe I called the guy back. I was like I don’t know who this person is, you know, it might be… Patient: Right, that’s a good point. Yeah. Doctor: Yeah and then, you know, there he was. Patient: Wow, wow. Doctor: So, then the next day when, you know, it was Monday afternoon my patient called and he goes okay, we’re never gonna do that again. I’m like, because he got his dose like Friday Patient: Right. Doctor: and then he traveled Sunday and I was like okay, that will teach you not to do that. So, now, I reported that back so now every single time, and they didn’t give him the card because they’re like it’s so low you won’t Patient: You won’t know yeah. Doctor: set off anything, you’ll be fine. After that incident, everybody gets a card. That’s a longwinded way of saying, everybody gets a card.

Patient: Uh-uh. Doctor: And have you been able to-? Any of these things come out to you? Have you already seen these labs or everything I’m going to tell you is new? Patient: You going to tell me new. Doctor: Let me see what I have. You had your bloodwork yesterday. So your white count’s normal. Huh, you’re anemic, been about the same. You’ve got normal platelets. So your iron stuff isn’t really helping, but, huh, your kidney test, liver tests, your potassium is on the low side so you take your supplement. You probably often forget one of them, one of them probably, I bet. Doctor: It’s hard to remember that second one. Blood sugar’s okay. One of your bone tests is still high, but not as high as it was last time. That doesn’t mean we’re going to do anything different. But, huh, and then your liver tests, kidney tests are normal. Huh, your testosterone says you have no testosterone. So the medicines we’ve been giving you are doing their job. Then your PSA has changed. Huh, it was twenty three months ago, twenty-eight when I saw you four weeks ago, and now it’s thirty-nine. Let’s see what we have for scans. I’ll look at your brain. Your brain looks fine. Now to this MRI. Really they don’t talk much about your bones. That’s good. Huh, let’s see. Your bone scan. Huh, did we have that last time as well? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay. So again, you’ve got the multiple sites of cancer in your bones, and you’ve got swollen glands down in your pelvis, don’t look like they’re from your cancer. Huh, let me see what I told you last time so that I am consistent. Okay. So what questions do you have for me? Patient: Huh, only one, I mean, huh, what are we going to do about this pain I’m feeling? Are we going to do what we’re doing? What we’ve been doing? Doctor: Yeah. I, I’m, I’m thinking we need to change. Huh, you know, get you off these pills and maybe go to chemotherapy. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Huh, chemotherapy’s got about a one in two chance of helping the pain. Huh, we could always radiate your bones if the pain doesn’t get better with the chemo. Huh, but I’d like to give you something that goes everywhere the cancer cells are, huh, so that, huh, huh, it’s a different approach than what we’ve done. Patient: Okay.

Family Member 1: You do nothing. Family Member: You do nothing. They’ll call you. Patient: Oh, you’ll call me? Doctor: I’m not going to call you. The pharmacy will call you. Patient: The pharmacy, right. Family Member: Pharmacy. Right. Patient: And if I don’t hear nothing, then how long, should I call you? Doctor: Give me a week. Just you know, if you use MyChart, you can give us a call. I’ll just follow up with them. They’re usually pretty good about it. Patient: Okay. Family Member: Okay. That’s it. Doctor: Other question you guys have? Patient: Do you want me to leave so you can talk?

Patient: Right. Doctor: So, for us to think about this trial as an option for you, we would have to restart the Xtandi – Patient: Uh, huh. Doctor: Check your PSA in a couple weeks and knowing that your ARV seven positive, it’s very likely that the PSA will still be higher. (Pause) Patient: Okay. Doctor: It’s different. It’s new. There is buzz out there, but the bottom line in prostate cancer is we don’t know how well these drugs work, if at all. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, it has less side effects than chemotherapy but has more risks than chemotherapy because if we do turn on your immune system really good, attack you, you could be bad. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay? Family Member: That’s if it ends up going bad versus -- uh, activated immune system. Doctor: We often use steroids, and we try to sort of dampen it – Family Member: Okay.

Family Member: In other words, when he eats it’s not going to be as wonderful. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: One of the things you enjoy. Doctor: But you know, if that's bad and we stop it and quality of life's terrible anymore Family Member: Well, with this neuropathy would this be something that would prevent him from being on this trial. Doctor: Well, you know, it’s yes, in the sense- Family Member: He definitely has it? Doctor: Right. If it's bad enough where you can't button, your shirt or you're constantly dropping things- Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: -or you're burning yourself or you're tripping all the time, that- Patient: My neuropathy is xxx. Doctor: Yeah. Okay. And you know, are you are you falling? Patient: No.

Family Member: No. He did not. Hum. Doctor: Okay. So did you explain anything to her? Patient: No. She tell me- Family Member: No. But, yes, this is why, right. Yes. This is why I’m here. Doctor: Ah. Okay. Family Member: Because I can’t get a good understanding. Doctor: Okay. Okay. We know the baseline stuff – Family Member: Right. Doctor: - that he has. Family Member: Exactly. Doctor: That’s basically still there. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: But because the PSA was doing a little bit of this creep up-

Patient: And that’s going to be in me for six months. Doctor: Yeah, like they give it to you - it’s like one minute, and you’re done for the month. Family Member: Does he have to keep that catheter in there for the whole month? Doctor: No. Family Member: Oh good. Doctor: Like you put it in (makes mimicking sound) Family Member: So you wouldn’t suggest that he does a lot of walking. Doctor: At this moment, I wouldn’t; I’d just chill out. Time to just kick back. You’ve moved in; don’t do anything else. Patient: We’ve got a lot of Christmas shopping to do. Family Member: I can do the Christmas shopping. Doctor: Why don’t you get on the scooter thing? Family Member: No, he ain’t gonna do that. Doctor: Oh my gosh!
